conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the current-carrying wire, we can use the formula for the magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor: F = I * L_eff * B.
F is the force, I is the current, L_eff is the effective length of the wire perpendicular to the magnetic field, B is the magnetic field strength.
The wire is folded into a right-angle shape with side lengths ac = L and cd = 2L.

premise: The wire is folded into a right-angle shape with side lengths ac = L and cd = 2L.
conclusion: The effective length L_eff is the straight-line distance between the endpoints a and d of the wire.

premise: The effective length L_eff is the straight-line distance between the endpoints a and d of the wire.
conclusion: This distance can be found using the Pythagorean theorem: L_eff = sqrt((L)^2 + (2L)^2) = sqrt(L^2 + 4L^2) = sqrt(5L^2) = L*sqrt(5).
Substitute L_eff = L*sqrt(5) into the force formula: F = I * L*sqrt(5) * B.
Simplify the expression: F = I * L*sqrt(5) * B.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the current-carrying wire is F = I * L*sqrt(5) * B.
